results.snippet: A Canadian astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia sent down Canada Day greetings today to Government leaders in Ottawa.         "I believe I have the best seat in all the house to wish you well," the astronaut, Dr. Robert Brent Thirsk, said in a...
results.lead_paragraph: A Canadian astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia sent down Canada Day greetings today to Government leaders in Ottawa. "I believe I have the best seat in all the house to wish you well," the astronaut, Dr. Robert Brent Thirsk, said in a videotaped message.

headline.main: NASA PICKS MODEL FOR A NEW FLEET OF SPACE VEHICLES

results.snippet: NASA selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation today to build a futuristic experimental rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space.         The wedge-shaped re-usable vehicle, the X-33, will be the first major...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation today to build a futuristic experimental rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space. The wedge-shaped re-usable vehicle, the X-33, will be the first major new spacecraft built by the United States in 25 years. It is a step toward replacing the space shuttle, and will be built under a program intended to move much of the initiative for developing high-risk technologies out of NASA's hands and into those of private industry.

headline.main: Gas Leakage May Delay Next Shuttle Flight

results.snippet: Hot gas seeped through joints in both rocket boosters during the launching of the space shuttle Columbia two weeks ago but did not damage the O-rings or endanger the shuttle or its crew, NASA said today.         Nonetheless, the problem could delay...
results.lead_paragraph: Hot gas seeped through joints in both rocket boosters during the launching of the space shuttle Columbia two weeks ago but did not damage the O-rings or endanger the shuttle or its crew, NASA said today. Nonetheless, the problem could delay the space shuttle Atlantis's flight to the Russian space station Mir and keep Dr. Shannon Lucid, a physicist and NASA astronaut, in orbit aboard the Mir longer than planned. Dr. Lucid, who is scheduled to return to Earth in August aboard the Atlantis, could end up spending an extra month there if the shuttle's solid-fuel rocket boosters have to be replaced.

headline.main: Astronaut May Stay in Orbit 6 Weeks Longer, NASA Says

results.snippet: Dr. Shannon Lucid says she is not worried about extending her five-month stay in space. After all, she brought along plenty of books to read.         Dr. Lucid, a 53-year-old biochemist and NASA astronaut, spoke from the Russian space station Mir...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Shannon Lucid says she is not worried about extending her five-month stay in space. After all, she brought along plenty of books to read. Dr. Lucid, a 53-year-old biochemist and NASA astronaut, spoke from the Russian space station Mir today, a day after officials said she might have to stay in orbit six weeks longer because of problems with the shuttle that is to retrieve her.

headline.main: Leaving the White House To a Medley of Memories

results.snippet: Col. John R. Bourgeois has had a closeup view at the White House for 38 years. He has played every Presidential Inauguration since 1961, and he let Bill Clinton, when he was still just the saxophone-playing Governor of Arkansas, jam  with him at a...
results.lead_paragraph: Col. John R. Bourgeois has had a closeup view at the White House for 38 years. He has played every Presidential Inauguration since 1961, and he let Bill Clinton, when he was still just the saxophone-playing Governor of Arkansas, jam with him at a governors' dinner at the White House. First as a member of The President's Own, as the United States Marine Band is known, and later as its director, Colonel Bourgeois has played at such varying events as the visits of the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev at the height of the cold war, the funeral procession of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 and the return of the American hostages from Iran in 1981.

headline.main: Astronaut's Ride Home Is Delayed for 6 Weeks

results.snippet: NASA yesterday delayed by six weeks the return of Shannon Lucid to Earth from a Russian outpost so as to replace rocket boosters on the shuttle that was to bring her home.         The Atlantis mission, which was to retrieve Dr. Lucid from the Russian...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA yesterday delayed by six weeks the return of Shannon Lucid to Earth from a Russian outpost so as to replace rocket boosters on the shuttle that was to bring her home. The Atlantis mission, which was to retrieve Dr. Lucid from the Russian space station Mir, was delayed from the end of July to mid-September so NASA could try to make sure that there was no trace of the sort of problem that led to the Challenger explosion a decade ago. It was a leaky booster rocket that destroyed the space shuttle Challenger in 1986, killing all seven crew members, including a high school teacher.

results.snippet: BUZZ ALDRIN, who made history when he became the second man to set foot on the moon, is on a voyage of a different sort this summer -- a book tour -- and he is returning to some of the earthbound haunts of his astronaut days. This afternoon, for...
results.lead_paragraph: BUZZ ALDRIN, who made history when he became the second man to set foot on the moon, is on a voyage of a different sort this summer -- a book tour -- and he is returning to some of the earthbound haunts of his astronaut days. This afternoon, for example, he will be at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, where 27 years ago today he blasted off on the historic Apollo 11 lunar mission. He will sign copies of his first novel, "Encounter With Tiber," which he wrote with John Barnes, a science fiction writer. The novel is being published this month by Warner Books. Tomorrow, he goes to the Epcot Center at Walt Disney World. "The book already sold out at the Houston Space Center," he said.

results.snippet: NASA today tentatively set Sept. 12 as the launching date for space shuttle Atlantis, which has been grounded by problems with its rocket boosters. The shuttle was supposed to blast off on July 31 for the Russian space station Mir to pick up the...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA today tentatively set Sept. 12 as the launching date for space shuttle Atlantis, which has been grounded by problems with its rocket boosters. The shuttle was supposed to blast off on July 31 for the Russian space station Mir to pick up the American astronaut Shannon Lucid, who has been on Mir since March. NASA delayed the flight last week to replace the Atlantis's solid-fuel rocket boosters. Hot gas seeped into booster segment joints during the shuttle Columbia's launching last month, most likely because of a new adhesive. The same adhesive was used in the Atlantis's boosters.

results.snippet: When a former astronaut writes science fiction, you have every reason to expect that it will champion the benefits of space travel against the doubters and penny pinchers in the scientific and political establishment. ENCOUNTER WITH TIBER...
results.lead_paragraph: When a former astronaut writes science fiction, you have every reason to expect that it will champion the benefits of space travel against the doubters and penny pinchers in the scientific and political establishment. ENCOUNTER WITH TIBER (Aspect/Warner, $21.95), by Buzz Aldrin and John Barnes, delivers the goods, and then some. Mr. Aldrin, the second man on the moon, has clearly lost none of his zest for launchings and landings, orbital insertions, aerocaptures, gravity assists and similar maneuvers necessary for getting a spaceship safely from here to there. His enthusiasm has led him, in collaboration with the author of novels like "Kaleidoscope Century" and "Mother of Storms," to concoct a 560-page novel of the near future with a simple premise: Space holds the answer to all our problems.
